comment:
Nose: strong  green Apple, walnut, unrippened banana, spice(slight cinnamon, wet oak

Taste: banana, cereal, nutty, long smooth, quiet finish

Mouth feel: smooth, thin...

Would love to meet in a dark alley.
Very smooth - worth the price for occasional usage

Tasted with Laura Hay during presentation. Did not write notes so this is based on simple memory. This was a very complex whiskey which I think was matured in sherry casks. It had some spicy fruit characters, smoky oak and quite warming as well. There was a lot going on and a lingering finish.
Smooth and easy to drink. Maybe too easy.
Starts off smooth and sweet but ends with a punch of spice and wood. A wonderful complex single malt to bring out for a special occasion.

Incredibly smooth, possibly even to a fault - but it's bold hint of fruity spice gives this incredibly easy to drink whisky a satisfying warmth. Quite possibly one of my favorite bottles for it's price point.

Lots of things going on as you would expect from a single malt in this price point: very smooth with flavors of fruit, smoke and wood. Medium finish with no dominate flavors, everything blends well together.
Now this Is a special Glenlivet. So smooth and priced reasonably. Good stuff
The best I've ever had. Smoooooth.
For the price, I expected more
Amazing speyside. Grande classe on peut pas se tromper.  Comme un grand cru classé.  .
So far the most expensive Scotch i have purchased.  Exceptionally smooth.  I will definately enjoy sharing this with close friends.
It was nice to experience once. I wouldn't  give it 5 stars due to the very sharp flavor

Chillin at the common cause drink up. Good whisky super mellow. Little sweet. Finish is really really nice.

I'm happy. Thanks jarred
Very nice. Smooth, tasty. If I'm being honest, I think I expected a bit more at this price point. Probably wouldn't buy again, but only because there's so many other decent whiskys to try yet !
Smooth, but a bit too iodiney for me
The scent of the 21 is similar to the buttery sweet 15, the taste is very smokey and very good.  Definitely my favorite Glenlivet, hands down.

Fist fill burbon cask. 5 or 6 burbon casks used in this whiskey. Enjoy it while you can. 

Pallet - hint of spice, can be enjoyed neat. Small hint of butter while holding on the pallet. 
Warm finish, welcoming, can enjoy all night beside a fire. 

By far my favorite scotch whiskey of all time.

Love at first sniff. This dram is smooth, smooth, smooth and definitely a drinker! Perfectly balanced however not to incredibly complex. The nose is sweet vanilla and inviting, the palette is mildly sweet with a touch of spice, smoke, and vanilla, the finish is beautifully smooth and keeps you coming back for more.
Very good. Distinct flavor of Glenlivet. Not quite as smooth as other brands.
I can see why it is so highly rated but I think it is good not spectacular

Glenlivet whiskies are always a little bit of a hit or miss with me (similar to Glenfiddichs), and this one is a miss unfortunately. If I could sum it up in a single sentence: it comes across as something that should have been bottled earlier. It just tasted overcasked, which is something I have rarely come across. Yes it's fruity (apples) and honeyed in the way you expect a Speyside, but the wood elements just don't work overall, like a tone deaf vocalist singing loudly in a choir. It's just too bad.
Very smooth.  Not very peety.  A little on the sweet side.  Very nice overall.

​
  Let me start by saying I owe the opportunity to taste this whisky to my brother. He bought this bottle for my Dad's 80th birthday. Only problem is my Dad is not really a whiskey drinker, and definitely not Scotch. This is definitely out of my price range, and after tasting it I'm glad I didn't pay for it.
  The Glenlivet Archive is a 21 year old expression matured in American oak and ex-Sherry oak casks. It is a beautiful dark amber color that attests to its 21 years in those barrels. There is no statement as to whether or not it is non-chill filtered, and is 43% ABV. Swirling in the glass produces a thick oily coating that produces nice long legs.
  Upon nosing this dram I immediately got caramel and toasted marshmallow with some toffee notes. After about 15 minutes in the glass it was still the same. I was hoping for more complexity from something this old but it just wasn't there. Maybe the taste would reveal more?
  In the mouth it has more of the same. Strong toffee sweetness with some oak notes. Others might pick up some other flavors but I couldn't. Just that overpowering sweetness.
  The finish finally produced something other than the caramel/toffee flavors, being fairly long and much drier with some peppery oak tones.
  This is a very good whisky, but considering the $110+ price tag, I can't recommend it very much. I've had better whiskies at half the price. Maybe not "better", but more complex and intriguing. I appreciate the chance to taste it, but I won't be saving up to buy a bottle. 3.5. Cheers!
Fruity, not too spicy, and very enjoyable
Geekfest 4. Smooth like water, fruity beginning, “dark” and slightly peaty. Very subtle and hard to classify. Is it plain or more complex than we realize? The jury is out.
Mild nose. Watery and mild palate. Toasted marshmallow. It's not until the finish that you can tell it's a Glenlivet. Lingers. Vanilla. Really nice.
From a very generous friend of Lianne. Smooth as expected of a 21
Sherry influence is strong.  Dark fruits, spice and a nice overall Scotch.  Nothing exceptional but very well done. 4/5
Warm and sweet, strong toffee and caramel flavour, fig, raisin, and oak notes. Not excellent but durable.
Warm, honey, lingers, toasted mallow, almond, vanilla buttercream
Sweet. Reminds me of apple juice.

It is very difficult for me to rate such a quality vintage product, with such a fine pedigree, this low.  This is the first >20yr scotch I have tasted.  I expected much more.  All the beloved distillery notes I love from Glenlivet products are missing.  Old musty smoke flavors arrive as the pour airs out in the glass.  I am not a big fan of smoke or peat.  Smoke overpowers other notes.  I was also expecting more richness and a more creamier mouth feel.  I think the 18 year might be the sweet spot at a much lower price point.(less than half)  I just can't abide $300 for this bottle.
Smooth, not alcohol taste, not wood taste, didn’t knock Harrison’s socks off
Not up to the 18 but very close. Smooth finish. Slight vanilla.
Smooth and very easy to drink. Sherry forward but somewhat balanced with light oaky char. Short-medium finish. Overall a great drink but 21+ years should deliver a bit more bang for the buck

Sherry, vanilla, dark fruits...It coats your mouth. A not too sweet and spicy finish.
Overall, an excellent whisky. 

One of my Top 5
So good. So smooth. Much better than the 18
how do people not like this?

This was amazing! Consumed as a neat dram at the Rehearsal Dinner for friend Richard Immel. 

Nose: balancing act between Sherry & Oak/Sandalwood. Very inviting
Palate: buttery soft mouthfeel with notes of dried fruit & dark honey 
Finish: was a long slow taper that begged for a return sip
Green apples on the nose. Bit short on the taste.

Strong notes, very flavourful, just right for a 21 years old. 

4.5/5

Nose- heavy sherry influence, maple syrup, cedar, raisins, soft vanilla

Palate- dried fruits, light honey, butterscotch

Finish- medium, chewy finish with spice and dried fruits

Nose is really nice, with heavy sherry. Palate is good, nothing special though, and not very complex. Finish isn’t very impressive either, and is just average. This is quite a disappointing dram IMO.

First glass from a new bottle. Neat, was standing for at least 30 mins. 
Had pistachios before. 

Nose: cherry and caramel 
Taste: rather smooth and rich, with a bit spice and acidity. Apricot?!
Finish: short, slightly bitter on the side of the tongue. 
Overall a nice whisky, but I am not sure it’s worth it’s money....
Delicious. Outstandingly smooth. Aromatic. Complex evolving flavour; a must have

Very clean smell. The sherry cask is there. Not pungent at all. Sherry up front on the taste with bourbon on the back. Right on the money with the peat. Extremely enjoyable.
Woody at the end
Colour of darkened cedar. Very light and fast legs. Nose of peppercorn, plums and slight orange peel. Palette of cinnamon hearts and caramel. Added water heightens orange and apple pie.

A beautiful expression of The Glenlivet that i was eager to taste. Finally i have had it and it was a fancy dram, easy drinkable and smooth, a little too straightforward maybe.

Bottled at 43%abv.

On the nose i really pick a lot of notes that i would normally get from the Glenlivet 15yo french oak. A very refined aroma. Vanilla cake, Raisins, Fruitcake. Amazing
And Fancy aroma, sherriness is present.
Custard cream and Pineapple.

On the palate, this is a wonderfully light whisky. Very smooth, Vanilla, custard cream and cake. Just as the nose.

Aftertaste is where something slightly is offered, a very bitter, truly bitter tobacco note (fantastic). Ginger. Super pleasant finish. 

Overall this is a fancy dram, made for people who can afford it and want a very smooth straightforward whisky. 89 over 100 is my score for it. Very pleasant experience.
